content:
##What are $\greenD{\text{perpendicular lines}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{parallel lines}}$?

$\greenD{\text{Perpendicular lines}}$ are lines that meet at right angles.  

[[☃ image 1]]

$\purpleD{\text{Parallel lines}}$ are always the same distance apart from each other — no matter how far they are extended, they will never meet.

[[☃ image 2]]

*Want to learn more about parallel and perpendicular lines?  Check out [this video](v/parallel-and-perpendicular-lines-intro).*

options.alt: Two lines that meet at right angles.
Two lines that will never cross.

content:
##Practice set 1: Identify parallel and perpendicular lines

[[☃ graded-group-set 1]]

*Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/recognizing-parallel-and-perpendicular-lines).*

gradedGroups.content:
**Which of the following pairs of sides in $\triangle GAZ$ are perpendicular?**

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
Look at the pair of $\greenD{\text{perpendicular lines}}$ below:  

[[☃ image 1]]

$\greenD{\text{Perpendicular lines}}$ meet at right $(90^\circ)$ angles.

Which sides in $\triangle GAZ$ meet at a right angle?

$\overline{AZ}$ and $\overline{GZ}$ meet at a right angle.  So, they are perpendicular.

[[☃ image 2]]

**$\overline{AZ}$ and $\overline{GZ}$ are a pair of perpendicular sides in $\triangle GAZ$.**

options.alt: Two lines that meet at right angles.

A triangle GAZ. The angle at Z has a box at its vertex connecting lines AZ and GZ. The angles at G and A are acute angles. Two green lines are laid on top of segments GZ and AZ and intersect at right angle Z.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1A

options.alt: A triangle GAZ. The angle at Z has a box at its vertex connecting lines AZ and GZ. The angles at G and A are acute angles.

gradedGroups.content:
Look at the flag of Trinidad and Tobago below, then answer the question based on the appearance of the lines on the flag. 

**Which statement about the two white stripes in the flag of Trinidad and Tobago is correct? **

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
Below are examples of $\greenC{\text{a pair of perpendicular lines}}$ and $\purpleC{\text{a pair of parallel lines}}$.  

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ image 2]]

We can compare these to the white stripes in the flag of Trinidad and Tobago.

Looking at the flag, we can see that the white stripes do not meet to form angles. 

Perpendicular lines meet to form $90^\circ$ angles, so the white stripes are **not** perpendicular. 

[[☃ image 3]]

We can also see that the white stripes are always the same distance apart and do not meet. 

**The white stripes in the flag of Trinidad and Tobago are parallel to each other.**

options.alt: Two lines that meet at right angles.
Two lines that will never cross.

The Trinidad and Tobago flag is red with a thick diagonal black stripe between two thin diagonal white stripes. Two white stripes are the same distance apart from each other and will never meet. Each white stripe has a line with arrows placed on top of it.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1B

options.alt: The Trinidad and Tobago flag is red with a thick diagonal black stripe between two thin diagonal white stripes. Two white stripes are the same distance apart from each other and will never meet.

choices.content: The white stripes are parallel to each other.
The white stripes are perpendicular to each other.
The white stripes are neither parallel nor perpendicular to each other.

gradedGroups.content:
**Is each pair of lines parallel, perpendicular, or neither?**

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

hint.content:
###First, let's look for $\greenC{\text{perpendicular lines}}$.

$\phantom{xx}$![])

[[☃ image 1]]

These lines meet at right angles, so they are perpendicular.

###Now, let's look for $\purpleD{\text{parallel lines}}$.

[[☃ image 2]]

[[☃ image 3]]

These lines will never meet no matter how far they are extended, so they are parallel.

###Finally, let's look at the remaining lines.

[[☃ image 4]]

These lines meet, so they are not parallel. They form two acute angles and two obtuse angles, so they are not perpendicular. 

|Parallel | Perpendicular | Neither

[[☃ image 5]] | $\huge\circ$  |  $\huge\bullet$ |  $\huge\circ$

[[☃ image 6]] |$\huge\bullet$| $\huge\circ$ |  $\huge\circ$

[[☃ image 7]]|$\huge\circ$ |  $\huge\circ$| $\huge\bullet$

[[☃ image 8]] |$\huge\bullet$| $\huge\circ$ |  $\huge\circ$

options.alt: Two lines that meet at right angles.
Two lines that are the same distance apart from each other and will never intersect.
Two lines that are the same distance apart from each other and will never intersect.
Two lines that intersect each other.
Two lines that meet at right angles.
Two lines that are the same distance apart from each other and will never intersect.
Two lines that intersect each other.
Two lines that are the same distance apart from each other and will never intersect.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1C

content:
##Practice set 2: Draw parallel and perpendicular lines

[[☃ graded-group-set 2]]

*Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/drawing-parallel-and-perpendicular-lines).*

gradedGroups.content:
Any pair of points can be connected by a line.

**Use the green line to connect the pair of black points that makes a line parallel to the blue line segment.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
Parallel lines are always the same distance apart from each other — no matter how far they are extended, they will never meet.  Below is an example of parallel lines:

[[☃ image 1]]

Now, let's look at all of the possible ways to connect the black points in the figure. 

[[☃ image 2]]

Which of these is parallel to the blue line segment?

**The answer**

[[☃ image 3]]

options.alt: Two horizontal lines that will never cross.

Four black lines intersect to form a quadrilateral. Each vertex of a quadrilateral is marked by a black point. Two diagonal black lines connect the black points in opposite angles of the quadrilateral. A blue line segment intersects the shape across five of the lines and at a distance from the sixth line such that it does not appear to ever intersect.
A blue line segment and a green line are at a distance from each other such that they appear to never intersect. Two black points are to the left of the blue line segment.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2A

gradedGroups.content:
Any pair of points can be connected by a line segment.

**Connect two pairs of black points in a way that creates two perpendicular line segments.**  
*Both line segments need to be moved.*
[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
Perpendicular line segments meet at right angles.  Here is an example:

[[☃ image 1]]

Now, let's look at all of the possible ways to connect the black points in the figure. 

[[☃ image 2]]

Which pair of line segments are perpendicular?

**The answer**

[[☃ image 3]]

options.alt: A horizontal segment and a vertical segment that meet at right angles.

Four black line segments form a quadrilateral. Each vertex of a quadrilateral is marked by a black point. Two black diagonal line segments meet at right angles and connect the black points in opposite angles of the quadrilateral.
Two diagonal segments that meet at right angles.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2B
